auto_merge.commit_message:
The called functions really should be "nogil", so enforce that before people start using it.

(Cherry-picked bug fixes from https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6829)

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
The called functions really should be "nogil" so enforce that before people start using it.

(Cherry-picked bug fixes from https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6829)

comment_data.body: This is just to fix warnings, right?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,12 +12,14 @@ cdef extern from *:
     void once_flag_init "__Pyx_once_flag_init"(once_flag*)
 
 cdef extern from "<threads.h>" nogil:
+    ctypedef void (*_once_func_type)() noexcept nogil
+
     # Threads
     ctypedef struct thrd_t:
         pass
     # Declare as noexcept because you'll regret trying to throw a Python exception from it
     # and nogil because it's a new thread, so you definitely don't have a Python threadstate yet.
-    ctypedef int (*thrd_start_t)(void*) nogil noexcept
+    ctypedef int (*thrd_start_t)(void*) noexcept nogil

comment_data.body: Ok, so this forces user functions to have a `nogil` declaration on them now. Adding this after the first RC seems pretty radical.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,12 +12,14 @@ cdef extern from *:
     void once_flag_init "__Pyx_once_flag_init"(once_flag*)
 
 cdef extern from "<threads.h>" nogil:
+    ctypedef void (*_once_func_type)() noexcept nogil

comment_data.body: It took me a while to guess that this is needed to fight the automatic "acquire the GIL" feature in the `print` statement. Would be nice to avoid this implicitness. I'd rather declare the whole file as `language_level=3` since that's what we'll (gradually) move to, so it's less hard on the eyes than this outdated "future" import, which sort-of asks for getting rid of it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,8 @@
 # mode: run
 # tag: cpp, cpp17, no-cpp-locals
 
+from __future__ import print_function
+

@@ -16,12 +12,14 @@ cdef extern from *:
     void once_flag_init "__Pyx_once_flag_init"(once_flag*)
 
 cdef extern from "<threads.h>" nogil:
+    ctypedef void (*_once_func_type)() noexcept nogil
+
     # Threads
     ctypedef struct thrd_t:
         pass
     # Declare as noexcept because you'll regret trying to throw a Python exception from it
     # and nogil because it's a new thread, so you definitely don't have a Python threadstate yet.
-    ctypedef int (*thrd_start_t)(void*) nogil noexcept
+    ctypedef int (*thrd_start_t)(void*) noexcept nogil

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    # For all these mutex classes, we strongly recommend you do not use any
    # blocking lock function while holding the GIL (try_lock should be fine though).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,10 +1,8 @@
 from libcpp cimport bool
 
-cdef extern from *:
-    # Not part of the C++ interface, but declaring this here so it isn't nogil
-    ctypedef void (*_once_func_type)() except+
-
 cdef extern from "<mutex>" namespace "std" nogil:
+    # For all these mutex classes, we strongly recommend you do not using any
+    # blocking lock function while holding the GIL (try_lock should be fine though).

comment_data.body:
Yes - in principle this could definitely break code.
(The equivalent C++ change is less important though - Cython always seems to select the generic function so the typedef is basically meaningless)

I think there's two cases:
* the user function genuinely doesn't need the GIL but isn't marked (which is a trivial fix),
* the user function does need the GIL, in which case they should mark it as `nogil` and do `with gil:` internally (which should be safe providing the call to `call_once` doesn't hold the GIL).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,12 +12,14 @@ cdef extern from *:
     void once_flag_init "__Pyx_once_flag_init"(once_flag*)
 
 cdef extern from "<threads.h>" nogil:
+    ctypedef void (*_once_func_type)() noexcept nogil

comment_data.body:
> which should be safe providing the call to `call_once` doesn't hold the GIL

~â€¦ so, why isn't `call_once` declared as `nogil` itself?~

Strike that. The whole block is `nogil`, so that's fine and matches the function argument now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,12 +12,14 @@ cdef extern from *:
     void once_flag_init "__Pyx_once_flag_init"(once_flag*)
 
 cdef extern from "<threads.h>" nogil:
+    ctypedef void (*_once_func_type)() noexcept nogil

comment_data.body:
Because it's in a `nogil` block so every function there is `nogil`.

We could add `nogil` to the definition to make it explicit though. But that would just be for documentation really.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,12 +12,14 @@ cdef extern from *:
     void once_flag_init "__Pyx_once_flag_init"(once_flag*)
 
 cdef extern from "<threads.h>" nogil:
+    ctypedef void (*_once_func_type)() noexcept nogil

comment_data.body:
I think the declarations can be simplified to this:
```suggestion
cdef void call_me_once() noexcept with gil:
    print("Listen very carefully, I shall say this only once.")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -33,8 +40,9 @@ def test_unique_lock_more():
     # unlocked automatically when it exits scope
 
 
-cdef void call_me_once() noexcept:
-    print("Listen very carefully, I shall say this only once.")
+cdef void call_me_once() noexcept nogil:
+    with gil:
+        print("Listen very carefully, I shall say this only once.")

commit.message:
Some small bugfixes to call_once

The called functions really should be "nogil" so enforce that
before people start using it.

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Some small bugfixes to call_once
